Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Hi, nice idea.
Couple of comments:

1) So, according to instructions south "S" can not be in the given route? Why?

2) Is the plane you are moving on infinite? Say in the instructions, that there are no borders.

3) Wouldn't following reverse order mean, that you step on the same tile as the original route? If so, "retracing" already means that you can not follow the same path back. Keep it simple and avoid ambiguity and say you can not step on the tiles which you already visited on the original route.

4) Not sure, this is a easy puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: this is a good puzzle..... i think the big difficult in this puzzle is to understand how must be the path back to the start position... for me it was very helpful to search the meaning of the word "retrace".... and that word could be in bold! :)

Can you explain why, for validator 4 (NEEEEEEEEEE) any of:
WSWWWWWWWWW
WWSWWWWWWWW
WWWSWWWWWWW
..
WWWWWWWWSWW
WWWWWWWWWSW
are not valid ?

At first I thought the rule was 'you cannot land on a cell you visited and go in the same way or in reverse from what you did in the original route', meaning that if you were at some point on cell 1 2 and went 'N' on it you cannot do either of 'N' or 'S' on the same cell on the returning path. But on Test 2 (NEN) one of the solutions is "WSESW" -> we use E again on the same cell.

i had to search for the definition of retrace: "to go over or along (something, such as a course or path) again often in a reverse direction.".... now your test cases make sense for me. you could pass on steps from your previous path but not in the same direction.
I updated it. Please review it. Thanks

General
* It looks very much doable as a clash of code. Suggest to create this contribution as a clash of code instead, or increase the complexity of the puzzle.

Goal
* Please change "in the form of {{North (N)}} and {{East (E)}}" to "represented by the characters {{N}} (North) and {{E}} (East)".

* Please change "using the exact same route or reverse" to "retracing your original route or reversing it".

* Please explain how to determine which route to choose when multiple possibilities exist. For example, another return route for Test 2 may be ESWSW. 

Input
* Please format "route" as a [[variable]].

* Please change "(N, E) starts with N ends with N" to "({{N}} or {{E}})".

Output
* Please change "{{(W, S, E)}}" to "of {{E}} (East), {{S}} (South) and {{W}} (West) only".

Constraints
* Please change "[[route]]" to "length of [[route]]".

Cases
* Test 1: The answer should be ESSSW.

* Validator 1: The answer should be ESSSSSSSSSSW.

Thanks.
Thanks

Goal
* Please change "shortest path" to "shortest paths".

Input
* Please change "The input consists of" to "<<Line 1>>:".

* Please change
"{{(N, W, E)}} starts with {{N}} ends with {{N, E, W}}"
to
"({{N}}, {{W}} or {{E}}). The first direction is always {{N}}."

Output
* Please change "Find the path" to "<<1 or more lines>>: the path(s)".

* Please change "a string of" to "a string which consists of".

* Please delete the quotation mark after "only".

* Please change the last sentence as:
If multiple shortest paths exist, the output should display each path on a separate line, sorted alphabetically.

Cover picture
* Suggest to upload a cover picture for the puzzle.

Thanks.

the original route only involves N, W, and E. S can be only used in the return path to help balance the displacement back to the starting point.

yes moving on infinite but only find the shortest path.

You can visit the same tiles multiple times, but you can't use the same bridge twice and You can't simply walk backwards along your original route

Example:
5 - 2 -  3   Original route: N (1→2)
|    |    |   Valid return: ESW (2→3→4→1)
6  - 1 - 4    Valid return: WSE (2→5→6→1)
                  Invalid return: S (2→1) and
                  Etc. 
1,2,3,4,5,6 - tiles
(1 → 2), (2 →1) and etc are bridges. 

what do you think the difficulty of this puzzle? Do i need to change the difficulty?
Thanks
Yes, I add it. Thanks

Thanks for the feedback! You're right that "find all shortest paths" might be more grammatically correct. But in some test cases, there's only one shortest path so I kept the wording more general as "find shortest path home."
Thanks I updated it

"Find the all shortest paths" is grammatically incorrect and should be changed. The correct phrasing would be "find all the shortest paths". This works whether there's one or multiple shortest paths, so there's no need to avoid it for single-path cases. However, if you still want to explicitly indicate that the number of shortest paths may be one, "find all the shortest path(s)" is acceptable.
I’m just leaving the title as it is "Find the Shortest Path Home". I think its okay or change to "find all the shortest paths"  what do you think?
The title's fine. The issue is in Goal section only.
how about this "Find All the Shortest Path(s) to Home".

In Goal section, change:

Your task is to find the all shortest paths to return

to

Your task is to find all the shortest path(s) to return
Thanks for clarification I updated it

How is one supposed to understand this, when the instructions you give are: "... to your starting point without retracing any part of your original route or following the reverse order."

There is no mention of bridges and traveling over bridges. Rewrite the instructions for that they are clear. Because for me "retracing your original path" means you can not visit the same tiles. How is "reverse order" different from "retracing your path" is also not clear.

About the difficulty, I feel that writing path finding algorithms is not easy. Easy puzzles are the ones which require a couple of ifs to solve.

I think the Instructions is clear and okay

When solving the problem, understanding "retracing" is crucial thats why it is in bold and that is the challenge. Here’s what it means:

Segment: A segment is the connection between two vertices (points) along your path.
Retracing: If the original route includes a segment from point A to point B (or from B to A), then you cannot use that same segment again either in the same direction or in reverse when finding the return path.

Here, "retracing" means:
Not using any segment of the original route again: You cannot travel along any path that was part of your initial journey.
Not following the reverse order of the original route: You cannot simply reverse the sequence of moves from your initial journey.

You can visit the same vertex multiple times, but you must avoid using any segment (the direct connection between two vertices) that was part of the original route.

Thanks

Look I apprechiate your explanations, but think of it like this. Many people solve these challenges, many of them not native English speakers and many of them not geniuses. So, my rational is simply, if I can not understand the instructions without googling and chatGPTing what exactly the author of the puzzle thought that  "retracing" and "reverse order" means, then the instructions are not clear enough.

Maybe between CS students solving these things on a daily basis your instructions are clear, but the web site is codingGAME so the puzzles should be fun. And to be clear, it is not fun to spend an hour coding a solution only to then find out you did not understand what the author ment with the instructions.

Please don't take this the wrong way, my comments are nothing personal and I just want to make the puzzle better in the spirit of good and honest peer review.

I appreciate your comment and thank you for reviewing my puzzle. I understand your point, and I will try to update it to make it easier to understand. If you have any ideas or suggestions, please comment them so I can get more insight. Thanks!

1. Please change "For Example" to "For example".

2. In the example, it's confusing to use E, N, W and S to denote both the direction and the vertices. Suggest to rewrite as follows (also removing the unnecessary "-"s and reformatting the grid in monospace):

```
{{4}} - {{1}} - {{2}}
|   |   |
{{5}} - {{P}} - {{3}}
```

{{P}}: Starting Point
Original route: {{N}} ({{P}} → {{1}})
Valid return: {{ESW}} ({{1}} → {{2}} → {{3}} → {{P}})
Valid return: {{WSE}} ({{1}} → {{4}} → {{5}} → {{P}})
Invalid return: {{S}} ({{1}} → {{P}})

3. It should be sufficient without listing all the vertices and segments at the end of the example, I hope?

Thanks.
I updated it. Thanks

I feel this puzzle requires some clarification about "retracing" and "reversing" a route.

For example: There is an infinite grid of islands, each connected to their 4 adjacent neighbors by bridges. If a bridge has been used when going from the first to the last island (input), it cannot be used when going back to the first island (output). But any island can be part both of the original route and the returning paths.

You can visit the same island multiple times, but you can't use the same bridge twice and You can't simply walk backwards along your original route

Example:
5 - 2 -  3   Original route: N (1→2)
|    |    |   Valid return: ESW (2→3→4→1)
6  - 1 - 4    Valid return: WSE (2→5→6→1)
                  Invalid return: S (2→1) and
                  Etc. 
1,2,3,4,5,6 - islands
(1 → 2), (2 →1) and etc are bridges. 
If theres still questions you can comment it. Thanks

I understand it that way now, the example I gave was meant as an example of how you can clarify the statement (i.e. illustrate with islands and bridges).

For me, "reversing" a path is using every islands you used on the initial route, just in reverse order. But on this puzzle, using even one bridge you already used counts as reversing the path.

Would it be better if the following change is made?

from:
retracing your original route or reversing it

to:
retracing any part of your original route or reversing it

what do you think? if I change
from:
without retracing your original route or reversing it.

to:
without retracing any part of your original route or following the reverse order
I'm ok with your suggestion.
Maybe it'll be useful to add your example with digits to the example section?
